'''Wesley Wilson''' (October 1, 1893 – October 10, 1958) was an [[United States|American]] [[blues]] and [[jazz]] singer and songwriter.<ref name="AMG"/> His own stage craft, plus the double act with his wife and musical partner, [[Coot Grant]], was popular with [[African American]] audiences in the 1910s, 1920s and early 1930s.<ref name="Review">{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/complete-recorded-works-vol-1-1925-1928-mw0000435139 |title=Complete Recorded Works, Vol. 1 (1925-1928) - Coot Grant | Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date=1998-01-02 |accessdate=2014-01-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite book
| first= Sammy 
| last= Price
| year= 1989
| title= What do they want?: a jazz autobiography
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Bayou Press Limited 
| location= Wheatley, Oxford, England
| isbn= 1-871478-25-1
| page= 32}}</ref>

His [[stage name]]s included Kid Wilson, Jenkins, Socks, and either Sox Wilson or Socks Wilson. His musical excursions included participation in the oddly named [[duet (music)|duo]] of Pigmeat Pete and Catjuice Charlie.<ref name="AMG"/> Wilson recorded songs such as "Blue Monday on Sugar Hill" and "Rasslin' Till The Wagon Comes".<ref name="Dead">{{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1950.html |title=The 50s and earlier |publisher=The Dead Rock Stars Club |date= |accessdate=2014-01-31}}</ref>

==Biography==
He was born in [[Jacksonville, Florida]], [[United States]]. Wilson played both piano and organ, whilst Coot Grant strummed guitar as well as sing and dance.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web|author=Eugene Chadbourne |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/wesley-wilson-mn0000819705 |title=Wesley Wilson | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date=1958-10-10 |accessdate=2014-01-31}}</ref>

The duo's billing also varied between Grant and Wilson, Kid and Coot, and Hunter and Jenkins, as they went on to appear and later record with [[Fletcher Henderson]], [[Mezz Mezzrow]], [[Sidney Bechet]], and [[Louis Armstrong]]. Their variety was such that they performed separately and together in vaudeville, musical comedies, revues and traveling shows. This ability to adapt also saw them appear in the 1933 [[film]], ''[[The Emperor Jones (1933 film)|The Emperor Jones]]'', alongside [[Paul Robeson]].<ref name="AMG"/>

In addition to this, the twosome wrote in excess of 400 songs over their working lifetime.<ref name="Fuqua">{{cite book
| first= C.S.
| last= Fuqua
| year= 2011
| title= Alabama Musicians: Musical Heritage from the Heart of Dixie
| edition= 1st
| publisher= The History Press 
| location= Charleston, South Carolina
| isbn= 978-1-60949-157-4
| page= 151}}</ref>  That list included "Gimme a Pigfoot (And a Bottle of Beer)" ([[1933 in music|1933]]) and "Take Me for a Buggy Ride", which were both made famous by [[Bessie Smith]]'s recording of the songs, plus "Find Me at the Greasy Spoon (If You Miss Me Here)" (1925)<ref>{{cite book
| first= John
| last= Shepherd
| year= 2003
| title= Continuum encyclopedia of popular music of the world: Volume II
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Continuum 
| location= New York
| isbn= 0-8264-6321-5
| page= 92}}</ref> and "Prince of Wails" for Fletcher Henderson. Their own renditions included the diverse, "Come on Coot, Do That Thing" (1925), "Dem Socks Dat My Pappy Wore," and "Throat Cutting Blues" (although the latter remains unreleased)."<ref name="AMG"/>

Although Grant and Wilson's act, once seen as a serious rival to [[Butterbeans and Susie]],<ref name="Review"/> began to lose favor with the public by the middle of the 1930s, they recorded further songs in 1938.<ref name="AMG"/>  Their only child, Bobby Wilson, was born in 1941.<ref name="Review 2">{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/complete-recorded-works-vol-3-1931-1938-mw0000729885 |title=Complete Recorded Works, Vol. 3 (1931-1938) - Coot Grant | Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-31}}</ref>  By 1946, and after [[Mezz Mezzrow]] had founded his King Jazz [[record label]], he engaged them as songwriters.<ref name="AMG"/> In that year, the association led to their final recording session backed by a quintet incorporating Bechet and Mezzrow.<ref name="Review 2"/>

Wilson retired in ill health shortly thereafter,<ref name="Fuqua"/> but Grant continued performing into the 1950s.<ref name="AMG"/> In January 1953, one commentator noted that the couple had moved from [[New York City|New York]] to [[Los Angeles]], but were in considerable financial hardship.<ref>{{cite book
| first= Floyd
| last= Levin
| year= 2000
| title= Classic Jazz: A Personal View of the Music and the Musicians
| edition= 1st
| publisher= University of California Press 
| location= Los Angeles, California
| isbn= 0-520-23463-4
| pages= 169/172}}</ref>

Wilson died from a [[stroke]], aged 65, in October 1958 in [[Cape May Court House, New Jersey]].<ref name="Dead"/>

In 1998, his entire recorded work, both with and without Grant, was made available in three chronological volumes by [[Document Records]].<ref name="Albums"/>
